|1948 â Present
|1948 â Present
|The original flavor. A yellow-green-colored, lemon-citrus-flavored soda that was developed in the 1940's by Barney and Ally Hartman, who were beverage bottlers in Tennesse. A revised formula was created by Bill Bridgforth in 1958.
|The original flavor. A yellow-green-colored, lemon-citrus-flavored soda that was developed in the 1940's by Barney and Ally Hartman, who were beverage bottlers in Tennesse. A revised formula was created by Bill Bridgforth in 1958.

! scope="row" | Caffeine-Free Mountain Dew
! scope="row" | Caffeine-Free Mountain Dew
Line 137: Line 137:
|1988 â Present
|1988 â Present
|A no-calorie Mountain Dew that was first introduced in 1988.<ref name="Smith2006">{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Andrew|title=Encyclopedia of junk food and fast food|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4jIOEZ5F9fAC&lpg=PA188&dq=%22Diet%20Mountain%20Dew%22%201988&pg=PA188#v=onepage&q=%22Diet%20Mountain%20Dew%22%201988&f=false|year=2006|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, Conn|isbn=0-313-33527-3|page=188}}</ref> It was formerly known as âSugar-Free Mountain Dewâ until 1986, when it was given its current name. In 2006 Diet Mountain Dew was reformulated with a new âTuned Up Tasteâ, using a blend of sucralose, aspartame, and acesulfame potassium as sweeteners. The previous formulation was sweetened exclusively with aspartame.<ref name="dietdew06">{{cite press release|title=A New Tuned Up Taste Changes How Dew Does Diet|publisher=PR Newswire|date=8 March 2006|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/a-new-tuned-up-tastetm-changes-how-dew-does-diet-55282307.html|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> In limited areas in the United States, Diet Mountain Dew has treated water instead of carbonated water as a fountain drink.
|A no-calorie Mountain Dew that was first introduced in 1988.<ref name="Smith2006">{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Andrew|title=Encyclopedia of junk food and fast food|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4jIOEZ5F9fAC&lpg=PA188&dq=%22Diet%20Mountain%20Dew%22%201988&pg=PA188#v=onepage&q=%22Diet%20Mountain%20Dew%22%201988&f=false|year=2006|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, Conn|isbn=0-313-33527-3|page=188}}</ref> It was formerly known as âSugar-Free Mountain Dewâ until 1986, when it was given its current name. In 2006 Diet Mountain Dew was reformulated with a new âTuned Up Tasteâ, using a blend of sucralose, aspartame, and acesulfame potassium as sweeteners. The previous formulation was sweetened exclusively with aspartame.<ref name="dietdew06">{{cite press release|title=A New Tuned Up Taste Changes How Dew Does Diet|publisher=PR Newswire|date=8 March 2006|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/a-new-tuned-up-tastetm-changes-how-dew-does-diet-55282307.html|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> In limited areas in the United States, Diet Mountain Dew has treated water instead of carbonated water as a fountain drink.
â
|[[Image:Diet_Mountain_Dew.jpg|75px]]
+
|<!-- Do NOT place a non-free image here, per WP:NFTABLE -->

! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Red
Line 168: Line 168:
|2001 â Present
|2001 â Present
|A cherry-flavored Mountain Dew. Introduced in 2001, it was the first widely successful flavor extension; In its first year of production, Code Red increased overall sales of Mountain Dew by 6 percent.<ref name="CodeRed">{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/money/general/2002/05/07/pepsi-blue.htm|title=USATODAY.com -Marketers of colorful drinks dye for big sales|last=Howard|first=Theresa|date=8 May 2002|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> It was later released in [[New Zealand]] in 2009.
|A cherry-flavored Mountain Dew. Introduced in 2001, it was the first widely successful flavor extension; In its first year of production, Code Red increased overall sales of Mountain Dew by 6 percent.<ref name="CodeRed">{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/money/general/2002/05/07/pepsi-blue.htm|title=USATODAY.com -Marketers of colorful drinks dye for big sales|last=Howard|first=Theresa|date=8 May 2002|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> It was later released in [[New Zealand]] in 2009.
â
|[[Image:Mountain_Dew_Code_Red.jpg|75px]]

|<!-- Do NOT place a non-free image here, per WP:NFTABLE -->

|2002 â Present

|A no-calorie, no-sugar cherry-flavored Mountain Dew. Available in limited areas only, it was first introduced in late 2002.<ref name="livewirecodereddiet">{{cite press release|title=Pepsi to Electrify Summer with 'Mountain Dew Livewire'|publisher=PR Newswire|date=25 February 2003|url=http://www.pepsicollector.com/pressrelease/020203MtDewLivewire.htm|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
|A no-calorie, no-sugar cherry-flavored Mountain Dew. Available in limited areas only, it was first introduced in late 2002.<ref name="livewirecodereddiet">{{cite press release|title=Pepsi to Electrify Summer with 'Mountain Dew Livewire'|publisher=PR Newswire|date=25 February 2003|url=http://www.pepsicollector.com/pressrelease/020203MtDewLivewire.htm|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>

! scope="row" | Mountain Dew LiveWire
! scope="row" | Mountain Dew LiveWire
|2003 â Present
|2003 â Present
|An orange-colored, orange-flavored Mountain Dew. LiveWire was initially introduced in 2003 as a limited-edition flavor for the summer.<ref name="livewirecodereddiet" /> In 2005, after two years of limited summer releases, LiveWire became a permanent addition to the Mountain Dew product line.<ref name="Livewire05">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2005/03/29/review-mountain-dew-livewire-2/|title=Update: Mountain Dew LiveWire|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=29 March 2005|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> It appears that LiveWire became region-specific in 2011, as many areas across the U.S. began noticing its disappearance from shelves. It was also released in [[New Zealand]] in 2011.
|An orange-colored, orange-flavored Mountain Dew. LiveWire was initially introduced in 2003 as a limited-edition flavor for the summer.<ref name="livewirecodereddiet" /> In 2005, after two years of limited summer releases, LiveWire became a permanent addition to the Mountain Dew product line.<ref name="Livewire05">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2005/03/29/review-mountain-dew-livewire-2/|title=Update: Mountain Dew LiveWire|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=29 March 2005|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> It appears that LiveWire became region-specific in 2011, as many areas across the U.S. began noticing its disappearance from shelves. It was also released in [[New Zealand]] in 2011.
â
|[[Image:Mountain_Dew_Live_Wire.jpg|75px]]

Line 188: Line 188:
|2004 â Present
|2004 â Present
|A sea green-colored, tropical lime-pineapple flavored Mountain Dew introduced in 2004, available exclusively as a fountain drink at [[Taco Bell]] restaurants. On January 24, 2006, an internet hoax was posted about Mountain Dew Baja Blast soon to be available in 20- fluid ounce plastic bottles. Beverage reviewers have noted a similarity in taste between the Mountain Dew Game Fuel Alliance Blue limited edition flavor and Baja Blast.<ref name="bajablast">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2004/07/30/review-mountain-dew-baja-blast/|title=Mountain Dew Baja Blast|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=30 July 2004|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
|A sea green-colored, tropical lime-pineapple flavored Mountain Dew introduced in 2004, available exclusively as a fountain drink at [[Taco Bell]] restaurants. On January 24, 2006, an internet hoax was posted about Mountain Dew Baja Blast soon to be available in 20- fluid ounce plastic bottles. Beverage reviewers have noted a similarity in taste between the Mountain Dew Game Fuel Alliance Blue limited edition flavor and Baja Blast.<ref name="bajablast">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2004/07/30/review-mountain-dew-baja-blast/|title=Mountain Dew Baja Blast|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=30 July 2004|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
â

! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Pitch Black II

Line 198: Line 198:
|2007
|2007
|A red-orange-colored, citrus-cherry-flavored Mountain Dew first released in August 2007 for a total of 12 weeks to promote the release of [[Halo 3]], an [[Xbox 360]] game. Two years later, this flavor saw a limited return to shelves promoting the MMORPG [[World of Warcraft]]. It was sold under the name "Mountain Dew Game Fuel Horde Red" with redesigned packaging and a new counterpart flavor. It was officially announced that this flavor would once again return to shelves to coincide with the upcoming game [[Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3]]. Its taste has been compared to "LiveWire", "Code Red" and the energy drink AMP Overdrive (another drink sold under the Mountain Dew brand name).<ref name="GameFuel07">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2007/08/12/review-mountain-dew-game-fuel/|title=Mountain Dew Game Fuel Â» Citrus Cherry Mountain Dew based on Halo 3|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=12 August 2007|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
|A red-orange-colored, citrus-cherry-flavored Mountain Dew first released in August 2007 for a total of 12 weeks to promote the release of [[Halo 3]], an [[Xbox 360]] game. Two years later, this flavor saw a limited return to shelves promoting the MMORPG [[World of Warcraft]]. It was sold under the name "Mountain Dew Game Fuel Horde Red" with redesigned packaging and a new counterpart flavor. It was officially announced that this flavor would once again return to shelves to coincide with the upcoming game [[Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3]]. Its taste has been compared to "LiveWire", "Code Red" and the energy drink AMP Overdrive (another drink sold under the Mountain Dew brand name).<ref name="GameFuel07">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2007/08/12/review-mountain-dew-game-fuel/|title=Mountain Dew Game Fuel Â» Citrus Cherry Mountain Dew based on Halo 3|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=12 August 2007|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
â
|[[Image:GAME_FUEL_Halo_3.jpg|75px]]
+
|<!-- Do NOT place a non-free image here, per WP:NFTABLE -->

! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Supernova
! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Supernova
|2008, 2011
|2008, 2011
|A magenta-colored, strawberry-melon-flavored Mountain Dew with [[ginseng]].<ref name="supernova10">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2008/05/22/review-mountain-dew-supernova/|title=Mountain Dew Supernova|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=22 May 2010|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> One of the three âcandidate flavorâ finalists for DEWmocracy's âPeopleâs Dewâ national vote, it lost to Mountain Dew Voltage. It finished in 2nd place.<ref name="dewmocracy2008results">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2008/08/19/news-mountain-dew-voltage-wins-dewmocracy-vote/|title=News: Mountain Dew Voltage wins DEWmocracy vote|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=19 August 2008|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> This flavor was re-released as a part of the "Back by popular DEWmand" promotion in early May 2011 and stayed on shelves through July.<ref name=bevrev />
|A magenta-colored, strawberry-melon-flavored Mountain Dew with [[ginseng]].<ref name="supernova10">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2008/05/22/review-mountain-dew-supernova/|title=Mountain Dew Supernova|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=22 May 2010|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> One of the three âcandidate flavorâ finalists for DEWmocracy's âPeopleâs Dewâ national vote, it lost to Mountain Dew Voltage. It finished in 2nd place.<ref name="dewmocracy2008results">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2008/08/19/news-mountain-dew-voltage-wins-dewmocracy-vote/|title=News: Mountain Dew Voltage wins DEWmocracy vote|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=19 August 2008|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> This flavor was re-released as a part of the "Back by popular DEWmand" promotion in early May 2011 and stayed on shelves through July.<ref name=bevrev />

! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Revolution
! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Revolution
|2008
|2008
|A sky blue-colored, wild berry fruit-flavored Mountain Dew with [[ginseng]].<ref name="Revolution10">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2008/06/11/review-mountain-dew-revolution/|title=Mountain Dew Revolution|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=11 June 2010|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> One of the three âcandidate flavorâ finalists for DEWmocracy's âPeopleâs Dewâ national vote. Revolution held the majority amount of votes until the end of the promotion, when dropped to 3rd place and lost to Mountain Dew Voltage.<ref name="dewmocracy2008results" /> In 2011, The "Mountain Dew Throwback Shack" began to have a prize of "A Hidden Stash of Dew" which was then revealed to be glass bottles of Revolution with lab labels on them. Demand for Revolution has increased since Pitch Black, Typhoon, and Supernova were returning to shelves, but Mountain Dew said that there were currently no plans to rerelease Revolution.
|A sky blue-colored, wild berry fruit-flavored Mountain Dew with [[ginseng]].<ref name="Revolution10">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2008/06/11/review-mountain-dew-revolution/|title=Mountain Dew Revolution|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=11 June 2010|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> One of the three âcandidate flavorâ finalists for DEWmocracy's âPeopleâs Dewâ national vote. Revolution held the majority amount of votes until the end of the promotion, when dropped to 3rd place and lost to Mountain Dew Voltage.<ref name="dewmocracy2008results" /> In 2011, The "Mountain Dew Throwback Shack" began to have a prize of "A Hidden Stash of Dew" which was then revealed to be glass bottles of Revolution with lab labels on them. Demand for Revolution has increased since Pitch Black, Typhoon, and Supernova were returning to shelves, but Mountain Dew said that there were currently no plans to rerelease Revolution.
â
|[[Image:Mountain_Dew_Revolution_Resized.jpg|75px]]
+
|<!-- Do NOT place a non-free image here, per WP:NFTABLE -->
|-
|-
! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Voltage
! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Voltage
|2008 â Present
|2008 â Present
|A deep blue-colored, raspberry-citrus-flavored Mountain Dew with [[ginseng]]. This flavor was one of the three âcandidate flavorâ finalists for DEWmocracy's first âPeopleâs Dewâ national vote. It was released in stores on May 19, 2008 as a limited edition flavor so that people could taste test which flavor they like best before voting.<ref name="Voltage10">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2008/05/28/review-mountain-dew-voltage/|title=Mountain Dew Voltage|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=28 May 2010|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Voting ended on June 14 and it was announced on August 17, 2008 that Voltage was the final winner, and therefore, it became a permanent addition to the Mountain Dew family. It was officially released for sale on December 29, 2008.<ref name="dewmocracy2008results" /> It was later released in [[New Zealand]] in 2011 under the name "Electro Shock" and described as a "charge of wild berry flavor."
|A deep blue-colored, raspberry-citrus-flavored Mountain Dew with [[ginseng]]. This flavor was one of the three âcandidate flavorâ finalists for DEWmocracy's first âPeopleâs Dewâ national vote. It was released in stores on May 19, 2008 as a limited edition flavor so that people could taste test which flavor they like best before voting.<ref name="Voltage10">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2008/05/28/review-mountain-dew-voltage/|title=Mountain Dew Voltage|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=28 May 2010|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Voting ended on June 14 and it was announced on August 17, 2008 that Voltage was the final winner, and therefore, it became a permanent addition to the Mountain Dew family. It was officially released for sale on December 29, 2008.<ref name="dewmocracy2008results" /> It was later released in [[New Zealand]] in 2011 under the name "Electro Shock" and described as a "charge of wild berry flavor."
â
|[[Image:MountainDewVoltagein12ozcan.jpg|75px]]
+
|<!-- Do NOT place a non-free image here, per WP:NFTABLE -->

! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Game Fuel Horde Red
! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Game Fuel Horde Red
|2009
|2009
|In 2009, the original "Game Fuel" flavor returned to shelves for 10 weeks under this name in connection with the [[World of Warcraft]] video game. Horde Red is the same formula as the first Game Fuel flavor released in 2007; though the name and label design were updated to reflect the World of Warcraft theme.<ref name="HordeRed09">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2009/06/09/mountain-dew-game-fuel-horde-red/|title=Mountain Dew Game Fuel Horde Red Â» World of Warcraft Mtn Dew citrus cherry|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=9 June 2009|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
|In 2009, the original "Game Fuel" flavor returned to shelves for 10 weeks under this name in connection with the [[World of Warcraft]] video game. Horde Red is the same formula as the first Game Fuel flavor released in 2007; though the name and label design were updated to reflect the World of Warcraft theme.<ref name="HordeRed09">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2009/06/09/mountain-dew-game-fuel-horde-red/|title=Mountain Dew Game Fuel Horde Red Â» World of Warcraft Mtn Dew citrus cherry|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=9 June 2009|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>

|2009
|2009
|A blue-colored, wild fruit punch-flavored Mountain Dew flavor released alongside "Mountain Dew Game Fuel Horde Red" for a 10-week period in 2009. Like Horde Red, Alliance Blue was a promotional flavor for the video game [[World of Warcraft]].<ref name="allianceblue09">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2009/06/15/mountain-dew-game-fuel-alliance-blue/|title=Mountain Dew Game Fuel Allliance Blue Â» World of Warcraft Mtn Dew wild fruit Alliance Blue soda|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=15 June 2009|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
|A blue-colored, wild fruit punch-flavored Mountain Dew flavor released alongside "Mountain Dew Game Fuel Horde Red" for a 10-week period in 2009. Like Horde Red, Alliance Blue was a promotional flavor for the video game [[World of Warcraft]].<ref name="allianceblue09">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2009/06/15/mountain-dew-game-fuel-alliance-blue/|title=Mountain Dew Game Fuel Allliance Blue Â» World of Warcraft Mtn Dew wild fruit Alliance Blue soda|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=15 June 2009|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>

! scope="row" | Diet Mountain Dew Ultra Violet
Line 233: Line 233:
|2009 â Present
|2009 â Present
|A variation of Mountain Dew in the U.S. consisting of natural sugar in place of high fructose corn syrup, first released in a limited production run during the summer of 2009.<ref name="hfcs" /> Mountain Dew Throwback has since been re-released for brief periods (generally 8â12 weeks at a time), including a 2nd wave from December 2009 - February 2010<ref name="throwback2nd" /> and a 3rd wave in Summer/Fall 2010.<ref name="throwback3rd" /> A fourth limited production run began in March 2011, lasting for a total of eight weeks before becoming a permanent addition.<ref name="limitedreleasestatus" />
|A variation of Mountain Dew in the U.S. consisting of natural sugar in place of high fructose corn syrup, first released in a limited production run during the summer of 2009.<ref name="hfcs" /> Mountain Dew Throwback has since been re-released for brief periods (generally 8â12 weeks at a time), including a 2nd wave from December 2009 - February 2010<ref name="throwback2nd" /> and a 3rd wave in Summer/Fall 2010.<ref name="throwback3rd" /> A fourth limited production run began in March 2011, lasting for a total of eight weeks before becoming a permanent addition.<ref name="limitedreleasestatus" />
â
|[[Image:Mountain_Dew_Throwback_2010.jpg|75px]]
+
|<!-- Do NOT place a non-free image here, per WP:NFTABLE -->

! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Cherry Fusion
! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Cherry Fusion
Line 243: Line 243:
|2010 â present
|2010 â present
|A white-colored, smooth citrus-flavored Mountain Dew. Part of the second Mountain Dew "DEWmocracy: Collective Intelligence" promotion. It was released in stores on April 19 as a limited edition flavor so that people could taste test which flavor they like best before voting. Voting ended on June 14, and it was announced that White Out had won the campaign, so it became a permanent addition to the Mountain Dew family. It had 44% out of all votes and was officially for sale on October 4, 2010. It has been available in slurpee form since January 2011 and was later released in [[New Zealand]] in 2011.<ref name="whiteout10">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2010/04/28/mountain-dew-white-out/|title=Mountain Dew White Out Â» Smooth Citrus Mtn Dew DEWmocracy Flavor|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=28 April 2010|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
|A white-colored, smooth citrus-flavored Mountain Dew. Part of the second Mountain Dew "DEWmocracy: Collective Intelligence" promotion. It was released in stores on April 19 as a limited edition flavor so that people could taste test which flavor they like best before voting. Voting ended on June 14, and it was announced that White Out had won the campaign, so it became a permanent addition to the Mountain Dew family. It had 44% out of all votes and was officially for sale on October 4, 2010. It has been available in slurpee form since January 2011 and was later released in [[New Zealand]] in 2011.<ref name="whiteout10">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2010/04/28/mountain-dew-white-out/|title=Mountain Dew White Out Â» Smooth Citrus Mtn Dew DEWmocracy Flavor|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=28 April 2010|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
â
|[[Image:Mountain_Dew_White_Out.jpg|75px]]
+
|<!-- Do NOT place a non-free image here, per WP:NFTABLE -->
|-
|-
! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Typhoon
! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Typhoon
|2010, 2011
|2010, 2011
|A red-orange-colored, strawberry-pineapple flavored Mountain Dew. Part of the second Mountain Dew "DEWmocracy: Collective Intelligence" promotion. It lost to Mountain Dew White Out and came in 2nd place with 40% of all votes. It was announced on April 15, 2011 that Typhoon would return in May 2011 as part of the "Back by Popular DEWmand" promotion and it stayed on shelves in 2-Liter bottles exclusively at Walmart Supercenters through July.<ref name="typhoon10">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2010/05/04/mountain-dew-typhoon/|title=Mountain Dew Typhoon Â» Punch of Tropical Mtn Dew DEWmocracy Flavor|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=4 May 2010|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
|A red-orange-colored, strawberry-pineapple flavored Mountain Dew. Part of the second Mountain Dew "DEWmocracy: Collective Intelligence" promotion. It lost to Mountain Dew White Out and came in 2nd place with 40% of all votes. It was announced on April 15, 2011 that Typhoon would return in May 2011 as part of the "Back by Popular DEWmand" promotion and it stayed on shelves in 2-Liter bottles exclusively at Walmart Supercenters through July.<ref name="typhoon10">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2010/05/04/mountain-dew-typhoon/|title=Mountain Dew Typhoon Â» Punch of Tropical Mtn Dew DEWmocracy Flavor|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=4 May 2010|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>

! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Distortion
! scope="row" | Mountain Dew Distortion
|2010
|2010
|A dark green-colored, lime-flavored Mountain Dew. Part of the second Mountain Dew "DEWmocracy: Collective Intelligence" promotion. It lost to Mountain Dew White Out and came in 3rd place with only 16% out of all votes. Due to its similarity in color to the original Mountain Dew, Distortion was packaged in a clear bottle with a black label (as opposed to the green-plastic bottle with a green label used in the original Mountain Dew) in an attempt to avoid confusion.<ref name="distortion10">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2010/04/26/mountain-dew-distortion/|title=Mountain Dew Distortion Â» Lime Blasted Mtn Dew DEWmocracy Flavor|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=26 April 2010|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
|A dark green-colored, lime-flavored Mountain Dew. Part of the second Mountain Dew "DEWmocracy: Collective Intelligence" promotion. It lost to Mountain Dew White Out and came in 3rd place with only 16% out of all votes. Due to its similarity in color to the original Mountain Dew, Distortion was packaged in a clear bottle with a black label (as opposed to the green-plastic bottle with a green label used in the original Mountain Dew) in an attempt to avoid confusion.<ref name="distortion10">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2010/04/26/mountain-dew-distortion/|title=Mountain Dew Distortion Â» Lime Blasted Mtn Dew DEWmocracy Flavor|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=26 April 2010|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
â

|A Mountain Dew-flavored energy soda introduced in 2005 in {{convert|14|USfloz|ml|adj=on}} bottles.<ref name="mdx2005">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2005/11/21/review-mountain-dew-mdx/|title=Mountain Dew MDX|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=21 November 2005|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> In 2006 its packaging format was transitioned to {{convert|20|USfloz|ml|adj=on}} bottles.<ref name="MDX2006">{{cite news|url=http://www.bevreview.com/2006/11/12/review-mountain-dew-mdx-20-oz/|title=Mountain Dew MDX 20 oz.|last=Tanner|first=Steve|date=12 November 2006|work=BevReview|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Its production was discontinued in 2007.
